_exec_summary.SummaryText:
5.0  Executive Summary

The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at your facility:  The facility complies with OSHA??A?s 29 CFR 1910.111 requirements for anhydrous ammonia storage, and it is the facility??A?s policy to adhere to applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If an emergency were to occur, it is KNC??A?s policy to notify Hamilton County Fire Department or the Hamilton County Sheriff??A?s Office.  

A description of the facility and the regulated substances handled: The Koch Nitrogen Company, LLC - Aurora Ammonia Terminal stores anhydrous ammonia in and distributes it from two refrigerated cylinder tank (60,000,000 pounds per tank) and one 200 ton bullet tank (400,000 pounds).  The total storage capacity of anhydrous ammonia at the facility is 120,400,000 pounds.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps: The facility complies with EPA??A?s chemical accident prevention rule (40 CFR 68) and applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.111 and relevant American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) standards.

Five-year accident history: An accidental release of anhydrous ammonia resulting in death, injuries, significant property damage, sheltering in place, or causing environmental damage on-site or off-site has not occurred within the past five years.

The emergency response program: In the event of an emergency involving the anhydrous ammonia system, it is the facility??A?s policy to notify the Hamilton County Emergency Management Agency and request that they respond to the emergency.  The facility has discussed this policy with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

Planned changes to improve safety: None identified at this time.
